level.text: Public assistance may be awarded to, or on behalf of, any needy individual who is eligible for one of the categories of public assistance established by subchapter II.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this subchapter, no person shall be rendered ineligible for public assistance by reason of a civil violation of § 48-1201.

level.heading: Effect of Amendments
level.text: The 2014 amendment by D.C. Law 20-126 added (b).

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 20-126
level.text: Law 20-126, the "Marijuana Possession Decriminalization Amendment Act of 2014," was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 20-409. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on February 4, 2014, and March 4, 2014, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on March 31, 2014, it was assigned Act No. 20-305 and transmitted to Congress for its review. D.C. Law 20-126 became effective on July 17, 2014.

level.heading: Expiration of Law 11-72
level.text: Section 401 of D.C. Law 11-72 provided that the act shall expire 5 years from the date of implementation of an approved federal waiver and rules promulgated by the Mayor.

level.heading: Editor’s Notes
level.text: Entitlement to public assistance: Section 10 of D.C. Law 9-271 provided that notwithstanding subchapter V of Chapter 2 of Title 4, medical and geriatric parolees shall be entitled to general public assistance pending their application for eligibility.
Section 501 of D.C. Law 20–126 provided that the Mayor, pursuant to subchapter I of Chapter 5 of Title 2 [§ 2-501 et seq.], may issue rules to implement the provisions of the act.
